parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build a markdown **fenced code block** CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find. Do not include any inline citations automatically generated by the deep research process (i.e., AI-generated or system-injected references i.e. 【deep research】 or ​:contentReference[oaicite). 

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand. Please provide the name or acronym of the first archaeology or historical studies-related software tool you'd like me to research.

Understood. I will conduct a systematic and thorough search for mentions of the archaeology-related software tool *recexcavAAR* from 1995 onward. I will collect and present data on each valid source found, recording:
- Year of the source (or n.d. if undated)
- Citation or page title
- URL
- Any concerns or uncertainties regarding data provenance or quality

I will compile the findings into a properly formatted quoted CSV within a fenced code block. I will update you once the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a systematic and thorough search for mentions of the archaeology-related software tool *recexcavAAR* from 1995 onward. I will collect and present data on each valid source found, recording:
- Year of the source (or n.d. if undated)
- Citation or page title
- URL
- Any concerns or uncertainties regarding data provenance or quality

I will compile the findings into a properly formatted quoted CSV within a fenced code block. I will update you once the research is complete.","title":"Systematic Evidence Collection for recexcavAAR","prompt":"Conduct a thorough and systematic search for the archaeology-related software tool *recexcavAAR* from 1995 onward. 

For each mention of this tool found in a source (academic paper, blog, repository, project page, etc.), extract and record the following information:
- "Tool": Maintain consistent naming, using *recexcavAAR*
- "Year": The year the source was published, or "n.d." if no date is available
- "Source": Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
- "URL": The full URL of the source
- "AI Notes": Any relevant concerns, uncertainties, or notes about the provenance of the data

Ensure each source is recorded as a separate row. 
- If the tool has a published repository, include information from its commit history.
- If the tool is discussed in scholarly literature, include each mention in a separate row.
- If found in blog posts or project pages, include them individually as well.

Format findings in a properly structured quoted CSV inside a markdown fenced code block. Do not include AI-generated references or inline citations. 

Be meticulous, reviewing all pages of search results. Expand search by ±1 year from any date found. If uncertain about any data point, indicate this clearly in the AI Notes column."}

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a thorough and systematic search for the archaeology-related software tool *recexcavAAR* from 1995 onward. 

For each mention of this tool found in a source (academic paper, blog, repository, project page, etc.), extract and record the following information:
- "Tool": Maintain consistent naming, using *recexcavAAR*
- "Year": The year the source was published, or "n.d." if no date is available
- "Source": Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
- "URL": The full URL of the source
- "AI Notes": Any relevant concerns, uncertainties, or notes about the provenance of the data

Ensure each source is recorded as a separate row. 
- If the tool has a published repository, include information from its commit history.
- If the tool is discussed in scholarly literature, include each mention in a separate row.
- If found in blog posts or project pages, include them individually as well.

Format findings in a properly structured quoted CSV inside a markdown fenced code block. Do not include AI-generated references or inline citations. 

Be meticulous, reviewing all pages of search results. Expand search by ±1 year from any date found. If uncertain about any data point, indicate this clearly in the AI Notes column.

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"recexcavAAR","2017","cran.r-project.org (Package recexcavAAR: 3D Reconstruction of Archaeological Excavations)","https://cran.r-project.org/package=recexcavAAR","CRAN official package page. Version 0.3.0 published Feb 25, 2017; initial CRAN release (v0.2.1) in 2016. Authoritative source, no provenance issues."
"recexcavAAR","2016","github.com (ISAAKiel/recexcavAAR repository)","https://github.com/ISAAKiel/recexcavAAR","GitHub source code repository. Development started ~2016; 223 commits through 2020. Marked 'inactive' (stable, no active development). Maintained by Clemens Schmid (nevrome)."
"recexcavAAR","n.d.","open-archaeo.info (recexcavAAR listing)","https://open-archaeo.info/post/recexcavaar/","Open-Archaeo (community list of archaeology software) entry. No date provided (archived in Jan 2021). Brief description with links to CRAN and GitHub. Data provenance: user-contributed listing."
"recexcavAAR","2022","Journal of Open Source Software (Archeofrag: an R package for Refitting and Spatial Analysis in Archaeology)","https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.04335","Peer-reviewed article (Plutniak 2022) citing recexcavAAR as a tool for 3D excavation analysis (referenced as Schmid & Serbe 2017). Confirms academic recognition of the package."
"recexcavAAR","2023","Journal of Open Source Software (archeoViz: an R package for Visualisation, Exploration, and Web Communication of Archaeological Spatial Data)","https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.05811","Peer-reviewed article (Plutniak 2023) references recexcavAAR (noting it is no longer maintained) as prior work in 3D excavation visualization (cited as Schmid & Serbe 2017)."
"recexcavAAR","2021","Journal of Open Source Software (bleiglas: An R package for interpolation and visualisation of spatiotemporal data with 3D tessellation)","https://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.03092","Peer-reviewed article (Schmid & Schiffels 2021) mentioning recexcavAAR in context of related tools. Provides a citation (Schmid & Serbe 2017), indicating the tool's relevance to subsequent research."
"recexcavAAR","2018","John Wiley & Sons (Encyclopedia of Archaeological Sciences – R Coding and Modeling)","https://faculty.washington.edu/bmarwick/PDFs/Marwick-2018-R-Coding-and-Modeling-The-Encyclopedia-of-Archaeological-Sciences.pdf","Encyclopedia entry (Marwick 2018) on R in archaeology, which lists recexcavAAR among notable R packages. Indicates broader disciplinary awareness; secondary source (no direct technical details)."
"recexcavAAR","n.d.","github.com (benmarwick/ctv-archaeology – Archaeological Science Task View)","https://github.com/benmarwick/ctv-archaeology","GitHub repository for an (unpublished) CRAN Task View on Archaeological Science. recexcavAAR is included in the package list. Living document with no fixed publication date (community-curated)."
"recexcavAAR","n.d.","rdocumentation.org (recexcavAAR package v0.2.2)","https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/recexcavAAR/versions/0.2.2","Auto-generated documentation from DataCamp RDocumentation. Reflects package version 0.2.2 (circa 2016). No publication date; content taken from package help and README, provided for user reference."
"recexcavAAR","2019","rdrr.io (recexcavAAR: 3D Reconstruction of Archaeological Excavations)","https://rdrr.io/cran/recexcavAAR/","CRAN package mirror on rdrr.io. Documentation page compiled May 1, 2019. Shows package description, vignettes, authors, etc. Confirms details like version 0.3.0 and authorship (Schmid & Serbe)."
"recexcavAAR","n.d.","rpkg.net (recexcavAAR package info page)","https://rpkg.net/package/recexcavAAR","Aggregated package info and statistics. Notes first CRAN publication (2016-09-19) and last update (2017-02-25). Provides citation format for recexcavAAR. Not an official source; data aggregated from CRAN/GitHub."
"recexcavAAR","2016","stackoverflow.com (Q&A: 3D plot in R using persp3D - Axis issues)","https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40577408/3d-plot-in-r-using-persp3d-axis-issues","Stack Overflow answer (Nov 2016) by user 'nevrome' (the author) references recexcavAAR functions `spatialwide` and `spatiallong`. Illustrates early use of the tool in solving a practical problem."
```
